title: Earl Vaughan Jr.: Unlikely heroes key Scotland's win over Pinecrest
text:
Earl Vaughan Jr.: Unlikely heroes key Scotland's win over Pinecrest 
LAURINBURG - Zamir White is two years away from being the best senior running back in the country at the high school level. 
Pinecrest coach Chris Metzger isn't waiting for the Scotland star to be anointed. He's already given him the title as a sophomore. 
FAN CAM: Pinecrest at Scotland 
No doubt, White was stellar Friday, rolling up four touchdowns in Scotland's 35-31 win over fellow unbeaten Pinecrest. 
But before we hand Player of the Game laurels to White, a deeper look at the statistics shows something that helped him and the Scots get the win. 
Coach Richard Bailey warned his team during practice that they were going to have to pass the football more than they had against any opponent this year. 
SLIDE SHOW: Photos   
Bailey respected the Patriots defense and with good reason. As far back as the summer, Bailey told anyone that would listen that Pinecrest was going to be a good team. Nothing he had seen on video this fall has changed his mind. 
So he began exploring how Scotland could attack the Patriots through the air in the event White and the ground game were contained. 
"We had worked a lot on screens,'' Bailey said. "They play a lot of soft coverage, basically trying not to give up big pass plays.'' 
Moving into the spotlight for the Scots were unlikely heroes Dashaun Ferguson and Randy Leak, quarterback and receiver, respectively. 
When they got the word they were going to have to do more than normal, were there any sudden lumps in the throat or cold sweats? 
Not for a second. 
"It's always exciting knowing you're going to get the ball,'' Leak said. "I'm always ready. They've got a saying, big players make big plays in big games.'' 
Ferguson said it's all about being game ready. 
"When he calls your number, you've got to do what you do,'' he said. 
Their reaction wasn't a surprise to Bailey. 
"Both those guys are senior returning starters,'' he said. "It's great when you have that veteran presence. You've got to put your faith in those guys.'' 
Ferguson completed 16 of 19 passes for 199 yards and one score to Leak. He was 8-for-8 in the final half, all to Leak, who finished with 12 catches for 138 yards. 
What the pair did was take advantage of what Pinecrest was allowing, the classic football challenge of adapting and overcoming when the usual strength simply isn't enough. 
"The screens were what opened up our offense,'' Ferguson said. "They respected the screens. That led to the off-tackle runs getting open.'' 
The biggest play of the night for Ferguson and Leak came in the waning seconds of the game as Scotland faced fourth-and-4 at the Pinecrest 20. 
Instead of going to White, the call was a hitch pattern to Leak. Ferguson rolled to his left and hit Leak just beyond the first-down marker. Three plays later, White scored the clinching touchdown with 30 seconds left. 
"As a receiver, you've always got to be aware of where you are,'' Leak said. "I knew it was fourth and 4.'' 
The play went for 9 yards, which was 4 more than Ferguson said it was designed to gain. 
"We had one last shot and we made it happen,'' he said. 
Which is exactly how a couple of veteran seniors are supposed to deliver. Discuss Print Posted in Columns , 910preps , High school , Top news   11:36 pm. Updated: 12:36 am. Similar Stories
